I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During a consultation mission in August 2011, the Government of Lao PDR requested 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide complementary capacity development technical  
assistance (TA) for supporting decentralized rural infrastructure development to link up with the 
Sustainable  Natural  Resources  Management  and  Productivity  Enhancement  Project 
(SNRMPEP) 1  financed by ADB and the International Fund for Agricultural Development. The 
ADB TA consultation mission visited Lao PDR from 19–20 August 2011, and discussed the 
proposed TA for Supporting Decentralized Rural Infrastructure Development. Subsequently, the 
Government of the Lao PDR concurred with the overall design, scope, implementation, and 
financial  arrangements  outlined  in  the  TA  proposal.  The  TA  is  included  in  ADB’s  2012 
assistance program for Lao PDR. 2 The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
A.  Sector Context 
2.  The  agriculture  and  natural  resources  sector  in  the  Lao  PDR  makes  the  biggest 
contribution  to  gross  domestic  product  of  any  sector,  and  accounts  for  over  70%  of 
employment.3 Despite the importance of agriculture to the economy and to household incomes, 
agricultural technology, productive rural infrastructure (PRI), and farmer organizations remain 
underdeveloped. Over 50% of households are made up of smallholder subsistence farmers with 
an average income of about $200 a year. The majority of smallholders in the sector engage in 
low-productivity rice production. Poverty is closely linked to food availability, and almost 30% of 
the rural population remains food insecure. 
 
3.  ADB’s diagnostic assessments (footnote 5) identify low agricultural productivity as the 
core sector problem, resulting in high rural poverty levels. Sector transition (i.e., agricultural 
intensification,  diversification,  and  agro-industrialization)  is  largely  constrained  by  under-
investment  in  PRI.  Poor  infrastructure  and  supply  chain  logistics  also  limit  agribusiness 
development. In the Strategy for Agricultural Development, 2011–2020, the government aims to 
modernize and enable economic diversification to market-oriented agricultural production based 
on  a  ―lowland  approach  to  development‖  in  the  northern,  central,  and  southern  regions. 
Establishing PRI is critical to facilitating private sector participation in the value chain, and 
contributing to increased incomes for smallholder farmers. ADB’s ongoing assistance supports 
this strategic priority by addressing both ―hard‖ and ―soft‖ rural infrastructure deficits, through 
rehabilitation of irrigation systems and rural access roads, and enhancement of local capacities 
to  manage  the  infrastructure  for  market-oriented  development.  The  realities  of  enhancing 
provincial autonomy and the ongoing decentralization process also suggest a clear need for 
strengthening the capacities of local governments (provinces, districts, and village clusters) for 
infrastructure planning, and operation and maintenance (O&M) as a means to enhanced income 
earning opportunities and livelihoods. 
4.  The country partnership strategy for the Lao PDR emphasizes that ADB’s assistance will 
focus on improving policies and institutional capacity to support broad-based, private sector-led 
growth  through  boosting  productivity,  diversifying  production,  and  stimulating  off-farm

commercialization and value chain development through improved rural access, transport and 
mobility—including irrigation development and/or rehabilitation, and rural roads improvement. 
Through improved institutional and human resources capacity for PRI development, the TA will 
support this government priority. 
B.  Synergistic Value 
5.  ADB has provided consistent support to the government for the development of rural 
infrastructure.  Currently,  it  finances  the  SNRMPEP5 and  the  project  preparatory  TA  for 
Productivity Enhancement along the East-West Economic Corridor (EWEC) (footnote 1). The 
SNRMPEP has three components: (i) capacity building for agriculture and natural resource 
sector management,6 (ii) investment in resource management and productivity enhancement, 
and (iii) efficient project management. Subprojects will comprise a mix of rural infrastructure (i.e., 
rehabilitation of feeder roads and access tracks, and construction and/or rehabilitation of small- 
and medium-scale irrigation), together with ―soft‖ initiatives for farmer groups and technical 
extension services formulated in the districts. 
6.  The  capacity  development  TA  will  build  capacity  to  optimize  cost  effectiveness  of 
investments in PRI, and sustain the improved and rehabilitated assets, with particular emphasis 
on the SNRMPEP and proposed investments under the EWEC TA. Maintaining rehabilitated 
PRI is essential, as it has a direct impact on delivering and sustaining the intended benefits. 
Most  large-  to  medium-scale  irrigation  schemes  are  underperforming  due  to  inappropriate 
design  and  lack  of  O&M.  Systems  are  designed  around  rice  cultivation  and  require 
reengineering to cater to farmers’ demands to diversify to higher-value crops. Local authorities 
cannot  afford  to  finance  comprehensive  O&M  as  provincial  budgetary  allocations  are 
constrained;  consequently,  the  assets  inevitably  deteriorate.  The  ongoing  irrigation 
management  transfer  (IMT)  process  has  made  a  substantial  contribution  to  increasing the 
effectiveness of irrigation schemes. Water users associations (WUAs) have been charged with 
the responsibility of setting irrigation service fees. However, in many of the lowland irrigation 
schemes, recovered user charges are insufficient to maintain the operations of pumping stations 
that rely on expensive electricity. Poor construction quality and associated rehabilitation costs 
often exacerbate the organizational and maintenance burden. The collection of irrigation service 
fees  among WUAs  of  the  community-managed  irrigation  schemes  also  varies  in  terms  of 
methodologies, rates, and performance.7 A comprehensive review of the lessons learned from 
the IMT policy is required to address O&M sustainability, affordability, and the capacity of the 
WUAs for O&M of the irrigation schemes. 
7.  The provinces are responsible for funding periodic and routine maintenance of rural 
farm-to-market  access  roads  linked  to  irrigation  schemes,  placing  a  significant  burden  on

management  issue;  there  are  technical  issues  linked  to  identifying  economically  and 
environmentally optimal and locally adapted design criteria. For instance, rural infrastructure is 
directly vulnerable to the impacts of climate variability and change, as well as, indirectly, through 
changes to the surrounding environment. 
8.  The TA will focus on strengthening provincial and district capacity in planning and in 
O&M of PRI for selected districts included within the scope of the SNRMPEP and the EWEC TA. 
The TA scope includes (i) basic training in the principles and practice of designing PRI and 
associated O&M; (ii) higher-level training in geographic information systems (GIS) for planning 
and monitoring PRI investments; (iii) support to train, register, and certify WUAs and farmer 
groups in the target districts for participatory irrigation management under the IMT process; and 
(iv)  training  on  procurement  and  financial  management  associated  with  PRI  planning  and 
investments. 
C.  Lessons Learned 
9.  ADB  has  developed  valuable  experience  around  the  issue  of  maintenance  and 
sustainability of PRI. Previous successful projects supported by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction  clearly  suggest  that  empowering  grass-roots  communities  is  critical  to  ensuring 
ownership and responsibility for maintaining assets. Nonpayment and/or low levels of collection 
of O&M fees, and poor routine maintenance of rehabilitated assets are often directly linked to a 
lack  of  awareness  and/or  ownership  among  local  beneficiaries.9 The TA  design  draws  on 
experiences from ADB’s Northern Community Managed Irrigation Sector Project,10 and the  
Decentralized Irrigation Development and Management Sector Project.11 The scope of the TA is 
also  informed  by  the  lessons  learned  in  designing  ADB’s  Northern  Rural  Infrastructure 
Development Sector Project.12 The lessons from this suite of interventions suggest the need for: 
(i) rigorous evaluation of design alternatives, and effective control of civil  works costs; (ii) 
continuous  support  for  WUAs  on  improved  cultivation  techniques,  marketing,  routine  O&M 
activities, and scheme management; (iii) support for the collection of relevant data, bookkeeping 
and maintenance of records of irrigated areas; and (iv) enhanced participation of women in 
planning, implementation, and benefits. 
10.  The TA will also distill lessons learned and good practices from the activities of the 
government, ADB, and development partners. The Japan International Cooperation Agency is 
implementing a TA for participatory irrigated agricultural development along the Mekong River in 
Savannakhet province13 and initiating an investment project for rural access improvement in the 
five southern provinces. Technical knowledge and lessons identified under these interventions 
will closely inform TA implementation. Synergies with other development partners active in rural

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA will be improved quality of PRI assets in the target areas in the 
southern Lao PDR. The outcome of the TA will be strengthened local government capacity to 
plan, implement, and monitor PRI development. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The  TA  will  have  three  outputs:  (i)  enhanced  planning  and  design  methods  and 
maintenance regimes introduced for selected rural roads and irrigation schemes, (ii) improved 
project  implementation  practices,  and  (iii)  institutionalized  supporting  mechanisms  for 
participatory O&M and cost recovery. Key indicators will include documented training modules 
and a manual on best practice in PRI planning and O&M. Progress against these outputs will be 
measured by the government’s endorsement and/or application of improved methodologies, 
practices,  and mechanisms  in the  subproject  investments  under  the SNRMPEP.  Improved 
methodologies and practices will also be applied to other ongoing and planned investment 
projects in six districts.14 The TA will facilitate target community participation with a strong focus 
on mainstreaming gender considerations in project implementation for improved sustainability of 
project outcomes. Knowledge products will be distilled across all the outputs. In particular ―good 
practice‖ will be identified and captured in manuals related to design; and O&M and cost 
recovery of the target PRI schemes will be consolidated as part of a communication and 
knowledge plan for effective dissemination and learning. 
13.  The  success  of  the  interventions  will  depend  on  consistent  and  strong  support  for 
training measures and capacity development interventions by national and local government 
entities,  and  adoption  of  design  specifications,  upgrades,  and  associated  implementation 
practices by local governments (provincial, district, and village cluster officials). The success of 
the capacity development measures is also dependent on uptake of improved cost-recovery 
measures and management of irrigation schemes by WUAs. 
14.  The identified risks include staff turnover and the possibility that ongoing and/or planned 
investment projects fail to internalize improved methodologies and practices. To avoid these 
risks, central and provincial working groups will be established to coordinate TA activities with 
existing and planned investment initiatives. Target districts and model sites need to be carefully 
selected to build maximum synergy with ADB-supported projects and other initiatives for rural 
infrastructure development in the area. District working groups will provide critically important 
coordination among local stakeholders and across the various activities. 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction in the 
amount of $1.0 million, and administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart 
support in the form of staff resources, office accommodation, workshop and logistics support, 
and  other  in-kind  contributions.  The  government  in-kind  contributions  will  include  central, 
provincial, and district counterpart staff; office accommodation at central and provincial offices 
                                                
14 The TA will also build on the safeguard training and compliance manuals developed under the SNRMPEP.

5 
or  equivalent;  data,  administration,  and  clerical  services;  and  communication.  The  cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  Institutional arrangements under the TA will dovetail with the established implementation 
framework  under  the  SNRMPEP  to  optimize  synergies.  The  MAF,  represented  by  the 
Department of Planning (DOP), will serve as the executing agency. The TA coordination office 
will be established under the DOP, to attend to day-to-day implementation of the TA. In the 
provinces, separate provincial TA offices will not be established, but will be included in the 
existing provincial project offices under the SNRMPEP. The DOP will implement the TA in 
collaboration with the Department of Irrigation within MAF, provincial agriculture and forestry 
offices  (PAFOs)  in  target  provinces,  and  selected  district  agriculture  and  forestry  offices 
(DAFOs). Under the SNRMPEP, a national steering committee already exists, chaired by the 
vice minister of MAF with representation from key national agencies and provincial coordination 
committees. 
17.  The TA will be implemented over a 3-year period from July 2012 to June 2015. An 
estimated 84 person-months of consultant inputs  will be required (17 international and 67 
national). Required expertise will include rural development planning, agricultural engineering, 
O&M,  GIS,  environmental  and  social  safeguards,  gender  and  ethnic  groups,  and  financial 
management and procurement. ADB will engage a consulting firm using quality- and cost-based 
selection  (80:20)  and  simplified  technical  proposals.  Some  individual  consultants  will  be 
engaged for preparatory and supplemental assignments. Inputs from the team leader and rural 
development planner will be frontloaded during implementation to develop design and O&M 
protocols for proposed PRI assets and associated training components. The team leader will 
also  guide  the  development  of  the  knowledge  and  communications  plan.  Inputs  will  be 
sequenced to ensure transfer of responsibilities to the deputy team leader and agricultural 
engineer during the final year of the TA, to implement the established protocols and finalize 
knowledge products. All engagement of consultants will follow ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010,  as amended from  time  to time).  Procurement  under  the TA  will  be  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Costs  for  equipment, 
workshops,  local  training,  seminars,  conferences,  and  surveys  will  be  included  in,  and 
administered under, the consulting firm contract. The development of the TA GIS elements will 
focus on maximizing the use of existing GIS databases held by MAF and other line ministries 
and demonstrating their integrated application in PRI planning and implementation. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,000,000  to  the 
Government of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic to be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  for  Supporting  Decentralized  Rural  Infrastructure 
Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Team leader and rural development planner (12 person-months). The team leader will 
have a minimum of 15 years of relevant experience in planning and engineering for  rural 
development and infrastructure, especially in design and operation and maintenance (O&M); a 
master’s degree in engineering; and ideally a minimum of 5 years professional experience with 
similar characteristics in Southeast Asian countries, preferably in the Lao People’s Democratic 
Republic  (Lao  PDR).  The  specialist  will  take  overall  responsibility  for  the  activities  of  the 
consulting  team  and  will  ensure  the  timely  completion  and  quality  of  activities,  in  close 
coordination with the executing agency and implementing agency. The team leader’s tasks will 
include: 
(i)  Manage  the  consulting team  and  coordinate  with  other  consultants  engaged 
under the capacity development technical assistance (TA). 
(ii)  Manage  the  provisional  budget  allocation  for  equipment,  workshops,  local 
training, seminars, conferences, and surveys. 
(iii)  Assist the government in establishing central, provincial, and district working 
groups for effective TA implementation. 
(iv)  Assist the government in selecting target districts for participation in TA activities. 
(v)  Formulate  and  present  training  and  workshop  programs  for  key  staff  of  the 
central, provincial, and district governments who work with the TA project. 
(vi)  Supervise the implementation of the workshop and training programs. 
(vii)  Identify  and  supervise  specialized  studies  and  field  surveys  required  for  TA 
implementation. 
(viii)  Conduct quality control of deliverables by the consulting team. 
(ix)  Assist provincial agriculture and forestry offices (PAFOs) and district agriculture 
and forestry offices (DAFOs) in endorsing and adopting the deliverables. 
(x)  Facilitate involvement of government staff and villagers concerned. 
(xi)  Deliver  consultant  inception,  quarterly  progress,  and  completion  reports 
consolidating inputs by the consulting team. 
(xii)  Conduct and review training needs assessment of provincial, district, and village 
cluster officials, engineers, Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry staff, and other 
relevant stakeholders. 
(xiii)  Review existing data, conduct field reconnaissance, and develop rural productive 
asset inventories in collaboration with district staff. 
(xiv)  Conduct training of trainers and supervise cascading training approaches. 
(xv)  Develop  a  prioritized  list  of  each  district  for  potential  rural  infrastructure 
improvements based on existing information, field surveys, and interviews in 
collaboration with district staff. 
(xvi)  Develop a knowledge dissemination and communications plan and coordinate 
development of all knowledge products. 
(xvii)  Prepare the development of typical prototype designs with gender features and 
ethnic group perspectives for community irrigation systems and rural farm-to-
market roads. 
(xviii)  Review and update existing rural infrastructure O&M and user group guidelines. 
(xix)  Review existing agricultural support mechanisms. 
(xx)  Recommend a mechanism linking TA activities with existing agricultural support 
services,  and  assist  government  staff  in  delivering  the  services  to  target 
beneficiaries.

Appendix 3  11 
(xxi)  Test and develop checklists and manuals for construction supervision and site 
inspection in collaboration with provincial and district staff. 
(xxii)  Prepare documents for the Asian Development Bank (ADB) briefings, Embassy 
of Japan briefings, and quarterly financial and progress reports. 
(xxiii)  Liaise with key development partners, national agencies, and other stakeholders. 
(xxiv)  Support and organize the project steering committee periodic meetings. 
 
2.  Environmental safeguard specialist (1.5 person-months). The specialist will have a 
minimum of 15 years of relevant experience including environmental safeguard documentation, 
a relevant bachelor’s degree, and ideally a minimum of 5 years professional experience with 
similar characteristics in Southeast Asian countries, preferably in the Lao PDR. The tasks of the 
specialist will include: 
(i)  Review  existing  environmental  and  social  safeguard  documentation  following 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) and prepare a sample environmental 
examination in a potential project site in collaboration with the provincial and 
district staff. 
(ii)  Develop checklists and manuals for preparing, implementing, and monitoring 
initial environmental examinations based on an assessment of the key gaps 
between  the  government  and  ADB  environmental  safeguard  standards  and 
recommend a strategy towards narrowing the gaps. 
(iii)  Conduct on-the-job training for government staff and workshops to disseminate 
the deliverables. 
(iv)  Prepare a workshop and training program and materials. 
(v)  Provide inputs for TA reports. 
 
3.  Social safeguard and gender specialist (1.5 person-months). The specialist will have 
a minimum of 15 years of relevant experience including social safeguard documentation, a 
relevant bacherlor’s degree, and ideally a minimum of 5 years professional experience with 
similar characteristics in Southeast Asian countries, preferably in the Lao PDR. The tasks of the 
specialist will include: 
(i)  Review  existing  social  safeguard  documentation  following  ADB’s  Safeguard 
Policy  Statement  and  prepare  a  sample  resettlement  plan  and  ethnic  group 
development plan in a potential project site in collaboration with the provincial 
and district staff. 
(ii)  Develop checklists and manuals for preparing, implementing, and monitoring the 
resettlement plan and ethnic group development plan based on the samples. 
(iii)  Review existing gender action plans and other related initiatives, and prepare a 
sample gender action plan in a potential project site in collaboration with the 
provincial and district staff. 
(iv)  Develop checklists and manuals for preparing, implementing, and monitoring 
gender action plans based on the sample. 
(v)  Conduct on-the-job training for government staff and workshops to disseminate 
the deliverables. 
(vi)  Prepare a workshop and training program and materials. 
(vii)  Provide inputs for TA reports. 
 
4.  Procurement specialist (2 person-months). The specialist will have a minimum of 15 
years of relevant experience, a relevant bachelor’s degree, and ideally a minimum of 5 years 
professional  experience  in  undertaking  or  supervising  procurement  for  international 
organizations with similar characteristics in Southeast Asian countries, preferably in the Lao 
PDR. The tasks of the specialist will include:

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(i)  Review existing procurement capacity assessments of the Ministry of Agriculture 
and Forestry (and the Department of Planning) and of target PAFOs and DAFOs 
and make recommendations. 
(ii)  Develop  procedures  to  ensure  that  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010, 
amended  from  time  to  time)  are  incorporated  in  subproject  preparation  and 
implementation. 
(iii)  Prepare procurement strategy and standard bidding documents in accordance 
with national competitive bidding guidelines, in collaboration with the provincial 
and district staff. 
(iv)  Review the internal organization of the procurement function and assess and 
provide recommendations to improve linkages to both financial management and 
the budgeting process. 
(v)  Develop pro forma contracts that can be used for small-scale civil works. 
(vi)  Prepare checklists and manuals for procurement and contract management. 
(vii)  Conduct on-the-job procurement training for government staff and workshops to 
disseminate the deliverables. 
(viii)  Prepare workshop and training program and materials. 
(ix)  Provide inputs for TA reports. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
5.  Deputy team leader and agricultural engineer (24 person-months). The deputy team 
leader will have a minimum of 10 years of relevant experience, a relevant bachelor’s degree, 
and sufficient work experience with international organizations. The deputy team leader will 
have significant planning and engineering experience for rural development and infrastructure, 
especially in design and O&M. The deputy team leader will also have experience in training 
associated with rural infrastructure planning, use, and management. The tasks of the specialist 
will include: 
(i)  Coordinate activities of the consulting team with government staff and other 
stakeholders on a day-to-day basis. 
(ii)  Procure equipment, supplies, materials, and services. 
(iii)  Assist the government in implementing the TA activities. 
(iv)  Facilitate training and workshops, and assist PAFOs and DAFOs in endorsing 
and adopting the deliverables. 
(v)  Assist the team leader in conducting quality control of deliverables from the 
consulting team. 
(vi)  Facilitate involvement of government staff and villagers concerned. 
(vii)  Deliver,  in  collaboration  with  the  team  leader,  consultant  inception, quarterly 
progress, and completion reports consolidating inputs from the consulting team. 
(viii)  Facilitate TA activities in a target province as a provincial facilitator. 
(ix)  In  coordination  with  the  team  leader,  ensure  timely  implementation  of  the 
Knowledge Dissemination and Communications Plan and coordinate finalization 
of knowledge products. 
(x)  Review existing data, conduct field reconnaissance, and develop rural productive 
asset inventories in collaboration with district staff. 
(xi)  Develop a long list of each district for potential rural infrastructure improvements 
based on existing information, field surveys, and interviews in collaboration with 
district staff. 
(xii)  Conduct training and workshops for government staff. 
(xiii)  Revise a workshop and training program, materials, and deliverables, as required. 
(xiv)  Prepare summaries in Lao language and provide inputs for TA reports.

Appendix 3  13 
 
6.  Operation and maintenance specialist (18 person-months). The specialist will have a 
minimum of 10 years of relevant experience including rural infrastructure O&M and irrigated 
agriculture,  a  relevant  bachelor’s  degree,  and  sufficient  work  experience  with  international 
organizations. The tasks of the specialist will include: 
(i)  Assist the team leader and the deputy team leader in delivering outputs and 
managing TA activities. 
(ii)  Coordinate activities of the consulting team with government staff and other 
stakeholders on a day-to-day basis. 
(iii)  Facilitate TA activities in a target province as a provincial facilitator. 
(iv)  Prepare and implement a training and workshop program for rural infrastructure 
O&M. 
(v)  Revise and/or update O&M protocols as appropriate to be consistent with design 
standards and specifications. 
(vi)  Update O&M management regimes to include potential climate change impacts 
and recommend specific climate resilience measures for the rehabilitated assets. 
(vii)  Revise a workshop and training program, materials, and deliverables, as required. 
(viii)  Prepare summaries in Lao language and provide inputs for TA reports. 
(ix)  Coordinate agricultural inputs and extension services to optimize O&M benefits. 
(x)  Determine  cropping  systems,  labor,  pesticides,  and  other  general  criteria 
associated with improving operational and management efficiencies of systems. 
 
7.  Gender and indigenous peoples specialist (5 person-months). The specialist should 
have a master’s degree in social studies or anthropology and at least 10 years experience in 
working with gender issues. International experience will be an advantage. The specialist should 
be familiar with participatory planning approaches and adult learning methods. The tasks of the 
specialist will include: 
(i)  Collect, review, and utilize available studies based on gender and ethnic group 
disaggregated data to profile the situation of women in the area and identify 
gender-related cultural norms and practices to minimize exclusion of women in 
technical training and better respond to their needs. 
(ii)  Prepare  gender  action  plans  and  capacity  development-related  activities  in 
cooperation with other consultant specialists. 
(iii)  Recommend  specific  gender  design  features  of  the  entire  capacity  building 
program. 
(iv)  Identify  local  women’s groups  and  ethnic group  representatives,  assess  and 
suggest ways to strengthen their capacity for participation in committees. 
(v)  Prepare  and  conduct  gender  awareness  training  for  provincial,  district,  and 
village cluster officials and associated stakeholders. 
 
8.  Geographic information system specialist (5 person-months).The specialist will have 
at least 10 years experience in geographic information system (GIS), and a bachelor’s degree in 
geology, engineering geology, or environmental management. The specialist should also be 
familiar with participatory approaches and training activities. The tasks of the specialist will 
include: 
 (i)  Assess and identify training needs relative to progressive GIS and information 
technology capacity building for participating districts and village clusters. 
(ii)  Provide technical advice and guidance to local government officials. 
(iii)  Serve  as  resource  person  in  the  conduct  of  continuing  hands-on  GIS  and 
information technology capability training—in terms of data capture, processing, 
updating, storage, retrieval and sharing of data, and other application systems.

14  Appendix 3 
 
 
(iv)  Provide overall guidance and technical inputs in the development of customized 
GIS operation manuals. 
 
9.  Environmental  safeguard  specialist  (4 person-months). The specialist will have a 
minimum of 10 years of relevant experience, a relevant bachelor’s degree, and sufficient work 
experience with international organizations. The tasks of the specialist will include: 
(i)  Assist the international environmental safeguard specialist in delivering outputs. 
(ii)  Conduct training and workshops for government staff. 
(iii)  Revise a workshop and training program, materials, and deliverables, as required. 
(iv)  Prepare summaries in Lao language and provide inputs for TA reports. 
 
10.  Resettlement specialist (4 person-months). The specialist will have a minimum of 10 
years of relevant experience, a relevant bachelor’s degree, and sufficient work experience with 
international organizations. The tasks of the specialist will include: 
(i)  Assist  the  international  social  safeguard  and  gender  specialist  in  delivering 
outputs with regard to resettlement. 
(ii)  Conduct training and workshops for government staff. 
(iii)  Revise a workshop and training program, materials, and deliverables, as required. 
(iv)  Prepare summaries in Lao language and provide inputs for TA reports. 
 
11.  Procurement specialist (7 person-months). The specialist will have a minimum of 10 
years of relevant experience, a relevant bachelor’s degree, and sufficient work experience with 
international organizations. The tasks of the specialist will include: 
(i)  Assist  the  international  financial  management  and  procurement  specialist  in 
delivering outputs in the area of procurement. 
(ii)  Conduct training and workshops for government staff. 
(iii)  Revise a workshop and training program, materials, and deliverables, as required. 
(iv)  Prepare summaries in Lao language and provide inputs for TA reports.
